skill.name: exploratory-data-analysis
skill.description: Perform comprehensive exploratory data analysis on scientific data files across 200+ file formats. This skill should be used when analyzing any scientific data file to understand its structure, content, quality, and characteristics. Automatically detects file type and generates detailed markdown reports with format-specific analysis, quality metrics, and downstream analysis recommendations. Covers chemistry, bioinformatics, microscopy, spectroscopy, proteomics, metabolomics, and general scientific data formats.
skill.summary: Perform comprehensive exploratory data analysis on scientific data files across 200+ file formats. T...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate scientific data analysis skill with standard file I/O capabilities. The Python script reads user-provided data files, performs statistical analysis using standard scientific libraries (numpy, pandas, Biopython, Pillow), and generates markdown reports. No network calls, no credential access, no code execution vulnerabilities. All capabilities are necessary for the stated purpose of exploratory data analysis.

content.value_statement: Understanding the structure and quality of scientific data files is time-consuming and requires specialized knowledge. This skill automatically detects file type, extracts metadata, assesses data quality, and generates comprehensive markdown reports with actionable recommendations for downstream analysis.
actual_capabilities: Auto-detect 200+ scientific file formats from extension
Extract metadata and structural information from data files
Calculate statistics for numerical, sequence, and image data
Generate comprehensive markdown reports with recommendations
Identify data quality issues and missing values
limitations: Does not perform advanced statistical modeling or machine learning
Cannot analyze encrypted or password-protected files
Analysis is based on file extension detection (may fail for unknown formats)
Large files may be sampled rather than fully analyzed

use_cases.title: Quick data assessment
use_cases.description: Get immediate insights into experimental data quality and structure before detailed analysis

use_cases.title: Multi-format exploration
use_cases.description: Standardize analysis workflow across diverse scientific file formats in one tool

use_cases.title: QC reporting
use_cases.description: Generate consistent quality reports for instrument output files and datasets

prompt_templates.title: Basic file analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze the scientific data file located at [filepath] and give me a summary of its structure and content.

prompt_templates.title: Quality assessment
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a quality assessment on [filepath]. Report any missing values, outliers, or data integrity issues.

prompt_templates.title: Format conversion
prompt_templates.prompt: What Python libraries can I use to read [filepath]? What analysis approaches are recommended for this format?

prompt_templates.title: Multi-file comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare the structure and quality of multiple files: [file1], [file2], [file3]. Create a summary table of their characteristics.

output: Format: CSV with 15,000 rows and 8 columns
Columns: concentration, temperature, ph, time, yield, pressure, catalyst, solvent
Recommendations: Consider imputation for missing pressure values, check for outliers in temperature

best_practices: Provide full file paths for accurate analysis of large datasets
Use the generated reports as a starting point before detailed statistical analysis
Check the suggested Python libraries for format-specific features beyond basic analysis
Sample large files (100k+ rows) before running full analysis to save time
anti_patterns: Do not rely solely on extension detection for critical data with non-standard extensions
Avoid analyzing corrupted files without understanding the root cause first
Do not skip quality checks before downstream machine learning or statistical modeling
Avoid assuming all columns in tabular data are numeric without checking dtypes

faq.question: What scientific formats are supported?
faq.answer: 200+ formats including PDB, FASTQ, TIFF, CIF, HDF5, NetCDF, FITS, and common formats like CSV, JSON, Excel.

faq.question: What are the file size limits?
faq.answer: Large files are sampled (10k rows for CSV, 1k sequences for FASTQ) to maintain performance. Full analysis available for files under 100MB.

faq.question: Can this skill integrate with my analysis pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes, the eda_analyzer.py script can be called from other Python code or used as a standalone CLI tool.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: All analysis runs locally. No data is sent to external servers. Files are only read to generate reports.

faq.question: Why did analysis fail on my file?
faq.answer: Common causes: missing Python library for format, non-standard extension, corrupted file, or binary format not yet supported.

faq.question: How does this compare to pandas or Biopython?
faq.answer: This skill provides a unified interface across 200+ formats with automatic format detection and standardized reporting.
